case: Brown v. Board of Education, 347 U.S. 483 (1954)

queries.question: Who was the lead attorney in Brown v. Board of Education?
queries.answer: The lead attorney in Brown v. Board of Education was Thurgood Marshall.

result.o: Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal and violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka

nodes.content: Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#Person http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment A person involved in the case
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#TomClark http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Former U.S. Attorney General under Truman.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#mentored http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Mentorship chains are transitive
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#HugoBlack http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Former Alabama Senator. Despite KKK membership in 1920s, became strong civil rights advocate.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#EarlWarren http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Delivered the unanimous opinion. Secured 9-0 vote through careful negotiations.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#LindaBrown http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Third-grader denied enrollment in white school four blocks from home. Had to walk one mile to Black school.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#MamieClark http://law.gov/case#role Psychologist, Expert Witness
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#MamieClark http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Co-developed doll experiments with Kenneth Clark. First Black woman to earn psychology PhD from Columbia.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#OliverHill http://law.gov/case#role NAACP Virginia Attorney
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#OliverHill http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Pioneering civil rights attorney in Virginia.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#workedWith http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Legal team collaboration is symmetric
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#BrownVBoard http://law.gov/case#holding Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal and violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#BrownVBoard http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#EthelBelton http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Lead plaintiff in Belton v. Gebhart (Delaware case).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#GeorgeHayes http://law.gov/case#role Washington D.C. Attorney
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#GeorgeHayes http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Co-argued Bolling v. Sharpe with James Nabrit.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#HarryBriggs http://law.gov/case#role Student Plaintiff (South Carolina)
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#HarryBriggs http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Lead plaintiff in Briggs v. Elliott (South Carolina case).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#JamesNabrit http://law.gov/case#role Howard University Law School Professor
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#JamesNabrit http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Argued Bolling v. Sharpe (D.C. case).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#OliverBrown http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment African American welder from Topeka. Father of Linda Brown. Case named after him strategically.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#StanleyReed http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Last holdout. Warren personally convinced him to join unanimous opinion.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#BarbaraJohns http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment 16-year-old who organized student strike in 1951. Her actions led to Davis v. County School Board.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#DorothyDavis http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Plaintiff in Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County (Virginia case).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#HaroldBurton http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Former Republican Senator from Ohio.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#KennethClark http://law.gov/case#role Psychologist, Expert Witness
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#KennethClark http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Conducted famous doll experiments showing psychological harm of segregation on Black children.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#LouisRedding http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment First African American admitted to Delaware Bar. Argued Belton v. Gebhart.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#Organization http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment An organization or institution
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#RobertCarter http://law.gov/case#role NAACP Legal Defense Fund Attorney
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#RobertCarter http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Secured testimony from psychologist Kenneth B. Clark about segregation's effects on children.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#JackGreenberg http://law.gov/case#role NAACP Legal Defense Fund Attorney
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#JackGreenberg http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Argued the Topeka case. Later directed NAACP LDF from 1961-1984.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#RobertJackson http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Traveled to Court from hospital after heart attack to be present for unanimous decision.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#ShermanMinton http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Former Democratic Senator from Indiana.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#BeltonVGebhart http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Delaware case consolidated with Brown. Only lower court victory for plaintiffs.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#BollingVSharpe http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment D.C. case decided same day as Brown under Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#BriggsVElliott http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment South Carolina case consolidated with Brown
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#WilliamDouglas http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Longest-serving justice in Supreme Court history (36 years).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#PlessyVFerguson http://law.gov/case#holding Separate but equal doctrine
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#FelixFrankfurter http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Former Harvard Law professor. Instrumental in strategy to achieve unanimous decision.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#SpotswoodBolling http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label Spottswood Thomas Bolling Jr.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#SpotswoodBolling http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Lead plaintiff in Bolling v. Sharpe (D.C. case decided same day as Brown).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#ThurgoodMarshall http://law.gov/case#role Lead Counsel, NAACP Legal Defense Fund
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#ThurgoodMarshall http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment First African American Supreme Court Justice (1967-1991). Chief architect of the legal strategy in Brown.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#SpotswoodRobinson http://law.gov/case#role NAACP Legal Defense Fund Attorney
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#SpotswoodRobinson http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Argued Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County (Virginia case consolidated with Brown).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#TopekaSchoolBoard http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#TopekaSchoolBoard http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Operated segregated public schools under Kansas state law.
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#ConstanceBakerMotley http://law.gov/case#role NAACP Legal Defense Fund Attorney
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#ConstanceBakerMotley http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment First African American woman appointed to federal judiciary (1966).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#DavisVCountySchoolBoard http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#DavisVCountySchoolBoard http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Virginia case consolidated with Brown

value.o: Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal and violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka

queries.question: What was the significance of the 9-0 unanimous decision?
queries.answer: The 9-0 unanimous decision signifies a court case where all judges agreed on the verdict, highlighting the collaboration among key figures such as Thurgood Marshall, Robert Carter, and others who worked together on the case.

result.o: A person involved in the case
Former U.S. Attorney General under Truman.
Former Alabama Senator. Despite KKK membership in 1920s, became strong civil rights advocate.
Delivered the unanimous opinion. Secured 9-0 vote through careful negotiations.
Third-grader denied enrollment in white school four blocks from home. Had to walk one mile to Black school.
Co-developed doll experiments with Kenneth Clark. First Black woman to earn psychology PhD from Columbia.
Pioneering civil rights attorney in Virginia.
Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal and violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
Lead plaintiff in Belton v. Gebhart (Delaware case).
Co-argued Bolling v. Sharpe with James Nabrit.
Lead plaintiff in Briggs v. Elliott (South Carolina case).
African American welder from Topeka. Father of Linda Brown. Case named after him strategically.
Last holdout. Warren personally convinced him to join unanimous opinion.
16-year-old who organized student strike in 1951. Her actions led to Davis v. County School Board.
Plaintiff in Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County (Virginia case).
Conducted famous doll experiments showing psychological harm of segregation on Black children.
First African American admitted to Delaware Bar. Argued Belton v. Gebhart.
Secured testimony from psychologist Kenneth B. Clark about segregation's effects on children.
Argued the Topeka case. Later directed NAACP LDF from 1961-1984.
Traveled to Court from hospital after heart attack to be present for unanimous decision.
Delaware case consolidated with Brown. Only lower court victory for plaintiffs.
D.C. case decided same day as Brown under Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause
South Carolina case consolidated with Brown
Longest-serving justice in Supreme Court history (36 years).
Former Harvard Law professor. Instrumental in strategy to achieve unanimous decision.
Lead plaintiff in Bolling v. Sharpe (D.C. case decided same day as Brown).
Lead Counsel, NAACP Legal Defense Fund
First African American Supreme Court Justice (1967-1991). Chief architect of the legal strategy in Brown.
Argued Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County (Virginia case consolidated with Brown).
Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas
Operated segregated public schools under Kansas state law.
First African American woman appointed to federal judiciary (1966).
Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County

Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#JamesNabrit http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Argued Bolling v. Sharpe (D.C. case).
Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#OliverBrown http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment African American welder from Topeka. Father of Linda Brown. Case named after him strategically.

Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#LouisRedding http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment First African American admitted to Delaware Bar. Argued Belton v. Gebhart.

Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#BeltonVGebhart http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Delaware case consolidated with Brown. Only lower court victory for plaintiffs.

Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#SpotswoodBolling http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment Lead plaintiff in Bolling v. Sharpe (D.C. case decided same day as Brown).

Hypothesis: http://law.gov/case#ThurgoodMarshall http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment First African American Supreme Court Justice (1967-1991). Chief architect of the legal strategy in Brown.

value.o: A person involved in the case
Former U.S. Attorney General under Truman.
Former Alabama Senator. Despite KKK membership in 1920s, became strong civil rights advocate.
Delivered the unanimous opinion. Secured 9-0 vote through careful negotiations.
Third-grader denied enrollment in white school four blocks from home. Had to walk one mile to Black school.
Co-developed doll experiments with Kenneth Clark. First Black woman to earn psychology PhD from Columbia.
Pioneering civil rights attorney in Virginia.
Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal and violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
Lead plaintiff in Belton v. Gebhart (Delaware case).
Co-argued Bolling v. Sharpe with James Nabrit.
Lead plaintiff in Briggs v. Elliott (South Carolina case).
African American welder from Topeka. Father of Linda Brown. Case named after him strategically.
Last holdout. Warren personally convinced him to join unanimous opinion.
16-year-old who organized student strike in 1951. Her actions led to Davis v. County School Board.
Plaintiff in Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County (Virginia case).
Conducted famous doll experiments showing psychological harm of segregation on Black children.
First African American admitted to Delaware Bar. Argued Belton v. Gebhart.
Secured testimony from psychologist Kenneth B. Clark about segregation's effects on children.
Argued the Topeka case. Later directed NAACP LDF from 1961-1984.
Traveled to Court from hospital after heart attack to be present for unanimous decision.
Delaware case consolidated with Brown. Only lower court victory for plaintiffs.
D.C. case decided same day as Brown under Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause
South Carolina case consolidated with Brown
Longest-serving justice in Supreme Court history (36 years).
Former Harvard Law professor. Instrumental in strategy to achieve unanimous decision.
Lead plaintiff in Bolling v. Sharpe (D.C. case decided same day as Brown).
Lead Counsel, NAACP Legal Defense Fund
First African American Supreme Court Justice (1967-1991). Chief architect of the legal strategy in Brown.
Argued Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County (Virginia case consolidated with Brown).
Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas
Operated segregated public schools under Kansas state law.
First African American woman appointed to federal judiciary (1966).
Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County
Who was the lead attorney in Brown v. Board of Education?

queries.question: How did the Warren Court achieve consensus?
queries.answer: The Warren Court achieved consensus through collaboration among key legal figures, such as Thurgood Marshall working with Robert Carter, Jack Greenberg, and Constance Baker Motley, as well as partnerships like George Hayes with James Nabrit and Oliver Hill with Spotswood Robinson.

assertions.name: Cases in knowledge graph = 6 (Brown + Plessy + 4 consolidated)
Mentorship relationships = 3 (Marshall mentored Greenberg and Motley)
HyperFederate SQL shows attorneys with roles
OWL rules detected from TTL data
LAW STUDENT: Who were the key attorneys in Brown v. Board of Education?
